comments: I think that is what is left of the transfer. United will not want to pay 70-80 million upfront as that would be problematic. Not impossible.But difficult.
Haven't looked at our P&L for a while but you're correct, swiping £80+ off this years balance sheet would make it very difficult to complete many other transfers.

This is such bullshit

On the books any transfer of a player will be amortized over the duration the contract that is simply accounting standards. You buy a player for 5 years, you spread the cost of investment over those 5 years.

Has nothing to do with how that transfer will be paid which is a cashflow related matter. If United pays 85m in one lump sum it will still be amortized over the contract. The 2 things are unrelated as cashflow and accounting costs are 2 different things.

You know why that's bollocks?

Let's say we still sign Griezmann and keep Zlatan, who gets fit by December or January, but until Zlatan is fit we go with Griezmann and Rashford/Martial as our strikers. That doesn't make us considerably weaker, we still get a world class attacker join us and, best case scenario, get Zlatan back for the business end of the season to implement this Zlatan Griezmann partnership these tweets are saying Jose wanted. 

Worst case it doesn't work out, we cut our losses on Zlatan next year, still have Griezmann and sign another striker next summer. Thus splitting the cost of 2 brand new strikers up. 

Also this is without factoring in Rooney. However shite he was, he was another forward on £200k+ p/w who needs to be replaced. 

I don't buy it, but if it is true that then we're a bit silly.
Might be weaker, but collectively as a team, we may score more goals.

comments:
He's bang on. Simply buying a striker leaves us where we were last season. We need a few top quality attackers and I do the mean Perisic. 
Done with the window. Im not mentally strong enough for this rollercoaster
On paper he's right but a #9 that operates for the attacking unit rather than everything being about them could see our attack being greater than the sum of it's parts.
This is exactly the problem we'll find if we simply replace Zlatan and add Perisic to our attack. We'd basically be cementing our place as an upper-mid table club.

You know why that's bollocks?

Let's say we still sign Griezmann and keep Zlatan, who gets fit by December or January, but until Zlatan is fit we go with Griezmann and Rashford/Martial as our strikers. That doesn't make us considerably weaker, we still get a world class attacker join us and, best case scenario, get Zlatan back for the business end of the season to implement this Zlatan Griezmann partnership these tweets are saying Jose wanted. 

Worst case it doesn't work out, we cut our losses on Zlatan next year, still have Griezmann and sign another striker next summer. Thus splitting the cost of 2 brand new strikers up. 

Also this is without factoring in Rooney. However shite he was, he was another forward on £200k+ p/w who needs to be replaced. 

I don't buy it, but if it is true that then we're a bit silly.
Might be weaker, but collectively as a team, we may score more goals.

in_reply_to.text: Griezmann was seen as a supplement, not replacement for Ibrahimovic. By merely replacing Ibrahimovic United could maintain the status quo
